title: Canadian Electoral Reform
text: This article has been automatically fetched from a Polis poll that did not include a description.

comments.text: I can explain Arrow's Impossibility Theorem.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Defining the boundaries of electoral districts is best done by an independent body to reduce the likelihood of Gerrymandering.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Universal suffrage (voting rights for all regardless of ethnicity or gender) is a good idea.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Negative campaigning makes me so disgusted with all the candidates I don't really want to vote for any of them.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I want a voting system that reduces negative campaigning.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I like the simplicity of stating my favourite candidate, and who I hope will win if my first choice does not receive enough votes.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Instant Runoff Voting is criticized as "complicated," but is actually simpler than the strategic voting needed to vote effectively in FPTP
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Despite Maryam Monsef's claim, I do not feel "empowered" by mydemocracy.ca.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I can explain an Approval voting system.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I can explain a Condorcet voting system.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: MMP has a better chance of obtaining public support than STV due to its relative simplicity.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: STV's advantage over MMP is that it doesn't explicitly enshrine political parties in our electoral system.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: MMP is simpler to explain than STV.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: An electoral system can represent geographies, ideologies, and identities, but prioritizing one of these comes at a cost to the other two.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The Liberal party no longer supports meaningful electoral reform because they now have 55% of the seats with only 40% of the vote.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The Liberal party supported electoral reform in 2015 because they had 19% of the vote, but only 11% of the seats.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I feel that luring people in with the promise of engagement, and then sneakily trying to educate them, seems like a dirty tactic.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I think the government should demonstrate how different systems work based on last election results.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Election Day should be a civic holiday.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I identify as female.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The Conservative merger of 2003 was good for the party, but reduced the number of parties in Canada, decreasing our party diversity.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I have voted for a third-party candidate in a federal election.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I have moved and therefore voted in more than one riding in the past 10 years.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Outside of governmental elections, I have made use of alternate electoral methods.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I have voted knowing that the candidate for which I voted would win neither the most nor the second most votes.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I do not want my preferred party to have greater-than-proportional representation in parliament.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A dictatorship is arguably the least proportionate system possible.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A dictatorship, where only one vote counts, is an example of a disproportionate government.

comments.text: I would not want my preferred party to have disproportionate power.

comments.text: I can explain what Duverger's Law is.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: If given the choice between an electoral system with only two parties or one that's proportional, I would prefer a proportional system.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I am concerned that parties are  incentivized to advocate for electoral reforms that are self-serving.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I would like more choices of parties when it come to my vote
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I would like to vote for independent candidates if it was an option.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I want my vote to count, because it doesn't now.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I feel the current electoral system is undemocratic and biased.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I support a form of Proportional Representation or Mixed Member Proportional as an option for a new electoral system.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Politically similar parties are pressured to merge by FPTP to gain proportional seats, such as the Conservative merger in 2003.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Strategic voting results in people voting between the two most popular candidates.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: There is less incentive to vote strategically in proportional systems.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: First-past-the-post encourages strategic voting.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I feel that politically similar parties should have to merge in order to gain a more proportional percentage of seats.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Between 2011 and 2015, I felt that the Liberal's underrepresentation in parliament was unfair.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: If Canada reforms it's electoral system, it should be to one less susceptible to strategic voting.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I think Canada would be worse off if we had only two parties.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A party that receives less than 50% of the vote does not have a mandate to form a majority government.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Under a system of proportional representation, parties have less to gain by engaging in voter suppression of their political opponents.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Those who support overrepresented parties are more likely to oppose electoral reform.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Those who support underrepresented parties are more likely to support electoral reform.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Maintaining the anonymity of the secret ballot is more important to me than the convenience of voting online.

comments.text: Our current electoral voting system can be improved in a way that can better represent Canada's diversity of opinions.

comments.text: I think that a good consultation tool/process, be it digital or in-person, should allow participants (not just moderators) to shape conversation.

comments.text: Many of the comments here are difficult to vote on.

comments.text: There should be parties in Parliament that represent the views of all Canadians, even if some are radical or extreme.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: It should always be clear which party is accountable for decisions made by government, even if this means decisions are only made by 1 party
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Mandatory voting requirements will reduce the incentive for parties to  pander to extremist values
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 'Representative democracies' without PR often don't have real democracy, as parties can take complete control with a minority of the vote
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The party I most recently supported federally would benefit from the reform I would like to see.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Ballots should just show the candidates' names, not their parties, like they used to
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I live in an urban (not a rural) area
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The party I most recently voted for federally would benefit from the reform I would like to see
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: It's unacceptable to compromise on either the secret ballot or the verifiability of elections even if it would making voting more convenient
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I find it confuses the conversation when people misuse "ranked ballots" as a euphemism for "instant runoff voting"
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I want a fairer system than FPTP but not one in which MPs are appointed from a party list not selected by the public.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I understand how single transferable vote (STV) works.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I understand how mixed-member proportional representation works.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I think we need to develop a proper national "digital identity system" before we can consider implementing online voting.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Minority rights must be protected by Parliament.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Innovative ideas or proposals often seem radical or extreme until adopted by the mainstream.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Negotiations between parties to achieve a coalition government are more transparent than those between various factions in big tent parties.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Big tent parties may have a diverse membership but all policy-making is filtered to achieve party goals.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Voters want to be able to choose parties that offer distinct choices.  Under FPTP, apparent differences are too often only cosmetic.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: FPTP may seem like a simple voting system but most Canadians cannot figure out how to elect a MP of their own choosing.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Policies are neither efficient nor effective if they are not supported by most Canadians over the long-term.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Parties should be a tool to help MPs be effective representatives of their constituents but often see MPs only as their representatives.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A single MP cannot represent the government policy concerns of every constituent in his or her riding.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: There should not be a huge variance in the number of votes that each party needs to secure a seat in Parliament. All votes should be equal.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Both Conservative voters in the Atlantic and Liberal voters in the West deserve greater representation in Parliament.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: At present, no online voting system is immune to hacking, and therefore, is too risky for elections that matter.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: MPs in multi-member proportional ridings are more accountable to constituents because they face greater competition to be elected.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I'd rather have a MP in multi-member proportional riding that I voted for than a MP in a single-member riding that I did not vote for.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Ranked ballots added to a winner-take-all voting system reduce vote-splitting to allow the largest parties to win more majority governments.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Ranked ballots provide real choices for voters if they are used in a proportional voting system.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Winner-take-all voting systems (such as FPTP) encourage "dog-whistle" politics and pandering to swing voters with short-sighted policies.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Fairness should be a high priority in any voting system.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Winner-take-all systems (such as FPTP)reward regional parties, whose support is concentrated within a geographical area, with extra seats.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: All citizens deserve equal and effective votes.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The more seats that a party has in Parliament, the greater its influence on government policy developed within a coalition government.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Given how over budget Phoenix Pay is, as one example, the federal government probably isn't ready to correctly implement online voting.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Most countries which use proportional representation systems include a threshold a party must meet before it is entitled to any seats.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: In general, the more proportional the system, the lower the income inequality; the more majoritarian the system, the higher the inequality.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Proportional voting systems can be designed to provide both local representation and a Parliament that reflects Canadian diversity.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Governments are not accountable when most votes cast elect no-one and there are so many "safe" ridings under our current FPTP system
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Proportional representation will reduce wild policy swings and result in more long-lasting policies with a view to the future.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Proportional representation will reduce hyper-partisanship and promote greater collaboration and cooperation between parties.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Proportional representation ensures support of government policies by the broadest segment of Canadians- at the very least, a true majority
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The voting age should be lowered to 16.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I have a good understanding of alternative electoral systems.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I can explain the way our current electoral system works to a five year old.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I think a healthy system could involve giving groups too small to gain a voice (for example, Northern and Aboriginal communities), more seats than their small proportion.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I think a system involving proportional representation for perhaps 10% of parliamentary seats could be an improvement.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I would then roll back the growth in the number of ridings so that in total we have no more seats in total in Parliament than currently.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Something like 30 seats in Parliament allocated on the basis of % of votes and another 10 allocated to the North and Aboriginals.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I would like a system reflecting the percentage of votes and the views of groups too small to gain a voice.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I think my vote is wasted under the current electoral system.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I think we can and should come up with a cheaper and better way to run referendum-like national gut-checks.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: For online voting, I think we should base our decisions & timelines on the professional opinions of those in the digital security community.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The current electoral system leads to increased voter apathy and poor participation.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The allocation of seats in the House of Commons should better reflect the popular vote.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The current electoral system strengthens the dominance of the two major political parties, the Conservative Party and the Liberal Party.

comments.text: I am worried about security issues with online voting.

comments.text: The voting process is intimidating. I dont even understand why I would vote for different candidates.

comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The current electoral system does not represent voter preferences accurately and should be changed.

comments.text: I wouldnt trust online voting systems and would prefer to cast my ballot in person.

comments.text: If we used a system with proportional representation, the opinions would be too strongly divided and nothing would ever get done.

comments.text: The current electoral system results in more stable governance (ie: more majority governments which can serve a full term).
